title: 105_hr4093
content: The "Hospital Stay Protection Act" is cited as the short title. It establishes a standard relating to hospital lengths of stay for group health plans under the Public Health Service Act. The "Hospital Stay Protection Act" requires group health plans to provide inpatient coverage for a medically appropriate period determined by a physician. Plans cannot deny eligibility based on coverage requirements. The issuer offering group health insurance coverage must not deny eligibility based on coverage requirements, penalize providers for providing care, incentivize providers to reduce inpatient stays. The Secretary will establish an appeals process for participants to appeal plan decisions. The Secretary will establish an appeals process for participants to appeal plan decisions, including preauthorization for length of stay and penalties for violations. Group health plans must comply with notice requirements. The Secretary will establish an appeals process for participants to appeal plan decisions and impose penalties for violations. Group health plans must comply with notice requirements. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act are also included. Amendments are made to section 2723(c) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 by adding a new section. Amendments are made to section 2723(c) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 by adding a new section regarding standards for hospital lengths of stay. The new section requires group health plans to provide inpatient coverage for a medically appropriate period determined by a physician. Plans cannot deny eligibility based on coverage requirements. The issuer offering group health insurance coverage must not deny eligibility based on coverage requirements or penalize providers for providing care according to the new section. Incentives to providers to reduce inpatient stays are also prohibited. The Secretary will establish an appeals process for participants to appeal plan decisions and penalties related to provider care in accordance with the new section. The Secretary will establish an appeals process and penalties for plans or issuers that violate the provisions of requiring preauthorization for determining a length of stay. The imposition of these requirements will be treated as a material modification in the terms of the group health plan for notice purposes. The Secretary will establish penalties for plans or issuers that violate preauthorization requirements. The requirements will be treated as a material modification in the group health plan for notice purposes. The Secretary will establish penalties for violations of preauthorization requirements in group health plans. A summary description must be provided within 60 days after the first plan year in which the requirements apply. Conforming and clerical amendments are made to sections 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act. Section 711 and 713 of the Act are amended, along with section 732(a). The table of contents is also updated to include a new item after section 712. Section 713 of the Act is amended to include a new standard for hospital lengths of stay in individual health insurance. The provisions of section 2706 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements similar to those for group health plans. It includes a conforming amendment to the Act and specifies effective dates for group market reforms starting on or after January 1, 1999. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 1999. For group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before that date, the amendments do not apply to plan years before the later of the agreement date or the last collective bargaining agreement date. For collective bargaining agreements ratified before a certain date, the amendments made by subsections do not apply to plan years before the later of the agreement date or January 1, 1999. The termination of collective bargaining agreements related to the plan is determined without considering any extensions agreed to after the enactment of this Act or January 1, 1999. Plan amendments made to conform to new requirements added by subsections do not count as a termination of the agreement. The amendments made by subsection (b) apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market from January 1, 1999. Individual market amendments made by subsection (b) apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market from January 1, 1999. Coordinated regulations under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 are also amended. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 is amended to include provisions from other acts and codes.
